prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE0227-0913
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to map the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) and potentially CS(7-6) as well as the underlying thermal cold dust continuum of circumnuclear discs around luminous nearby AGN at a resolution of ~0.15-0.3".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select three spectral windows centered on the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) in Band 7 and an additional continuum window. Since we expect a line width ranging between 20 and 400km/s per beam we can use a correlator bandwidth of 3.9MHz (3.3km/s) which is a 1/5th of the narrowest expected line width to reduce the data rate. For the additional continuum band we will use the low resolution TDM mode.

We aim to resolve the CND around the AGN which we know from the existing MUSE observation have a size of <1kpc or <2". At the redshift of the AGN, 0.2" correspond to 70pc-150pc which allows us to resolve the CND in different physical regions. We will except spatial resolutions ranging between 0.15"-0.3" to be more flexible with the antenna configuration schedule since the targets are at the limit of night time observation for the preliminary Cycle 3 schedule.

By combining the integrated IRAM 30m CO(1-0) line flux with Halpha maps at 1" resolution from MUSE integral field spectroscopy (see Fig. 2) we re-distribute the CO(1-0) flux and roughly predict the CO(1-0) flux within <2" around the nucleus, i.e. 8.5 Jy km/s. We take into account the ratio between that area and the beam area of 100:1 but compensate with an assumed filling factor of ~10 and adopt a median line width of 50km/s to predict the CO(1-0) peak flux density, i.e. 17 mJy. We then consider the measured intensity ratios of the CND in the prototypical AGN NGC 1068, CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)>3, HCN(4-3)/CO(3-2)>0.15, HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)<3. Since HCO+ (2.5mJy) will be the weakest line we set the sensitivity such that we achieve a 5sgima detection adopting a 10km/s bandwidth splitting the line into 5 resolution elements. We will adaptively change the band width depending on the line width to achieve the same detection significance. Similarly we estimate the dust continuum based on the CO(1-0) flux within <2" that we convert into a gas mass of 3*10^8M_sun. We assume gas-to-dust ratio of 50, beam difference of 100:1 and a filling factor of 10, that leads to an expected dust mass of 10^6M_sun. For T=50K and Rayleigh-Jeans domain we expect a thermal continuum emission at 0.35mm of 0.06mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE0232-0900
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to map the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) and potentially CS(7-6) as well as the underlying thermal cold dust continuum of circumnuclear discs around luminous nearby AGN at a resolution of ~0.15-0.3".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select three spectral windows centered on the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) in Band 7 and an additional continuum window. Since we expect a line width ranging between 20 and 400km/s per beam we can use a correlator bandwidth of 3.9MHz (3.3km/s) which is a 1/5th of the narrowest expected line width to reduce the data rate. For the additional continuum band we will use the low resolution TDM mode.

We aim to resolve the CND around the AGN which we know from the existing MUSE observation have a size of <1kpc or <2". At the redshift of the AGN, 0.2" correspond to 70pc-150pc which allows us to resolve the CND in different physical regions. We will except spatial resolutions ranging between 0.15"-0.3" to be more flexible with the antenna configuration schedule since the targets are at the limit of night time observation for the preliminary Cycle 3 schedule.

By combining the integrated IRAM 30m CO(1-0) line flux with Halpha maps at 1" resolution from MUSE integral field spectroscopy (see Fig. 2) we re-distribute the CO(1-0) flux and roughly predict the CO(1-0) flux within <2" around the nucleus, i.e. 17 Jy km/s. We take into account the ratio between that area and the beam area of 100:1 but compensate with an assumed filling factor of ~10 and adopt a median line width of 50km/s to predict the CO(1-0) peak flux density, i.e. 33 mJy. We then consider the measured intensity ratios of the CND in the prototypical AGN NGC 1068, CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)>3, HCN(4-3)/CO(3-2)>0.15, HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)<3. Since HCO+ (5mJy) will be the weakest line we set the sensitivity such that we achieve a 5sgima detection adopting a 10km/s bandwidth splitting the line into 5 resolution elements. We will adaptively change the band width depending on the line width to achieve the same detection significance. Similarly we estimate the dust continuum based on the CO(1-0) flux within <2" that we convert into a gas mass of 8*10^9M_sun. We assume gas-to-dust ratio of 50, beam difference of 100:1 and a filling factor of 10, that leads to an expected dust mass of 2*10^7M_sun. For T=50K and Rayleigh-Jeans domain we expect a thermal continuum emission at 0.35mm of 0.12mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE1029-1831
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to map the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) and potentially CS(7-6) as well as the underlying thermal cold dust continuum of circumnuclear discs around luminous nearby AGN at a resolution of ~0.15-0.3".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select three spectral windows centered on the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) in Band 7 and an additional continuum window. Since we expect a line width ranging between 20 and 400km/s per beam we can use a correlator bandwidth of 3.9MHz (3.3km/s) which is a 1/5th of the narrowest expected line width to reduce the data rate. For the additional continuum band we will use the low resolution TDM mode.

We aim to resolve the CND around the AGN which we know from the existing MUSE observation have a size of <1kpc or <2". At the redshift of the AGN, 0.2" correspond to 70pc-150pc which allows us to resolve the CND in different physical regions. We will except spatial resolutions ranging between 0.15"-0.3" to be more flexible with the antenna configuration schedule since the targets are at the limit of night time observation for the preliminary Cycle 3 schedule.

By combining the integrated IRAM 30m CO(1-0) line flux with Halpha maps at 1" resolution from MUSE integral field spectroscopy (see Fig. 2) we re-distribute the CO(1-0) flux and roughly predict the CO(1-0) flux within <2" around the nucleus, i.e. 14 Jy km/s. We take into account the ratio between that area and the beam area of 100:1 but compensate with an assumed filling factor of ~10 and adopt a median line width of 50km/s to predict the CO(1-0) peak flux density, i.e. 28 mJy. We then consider the measured intensity ratios of the CND in the prototypical AGN NGC 1068, CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)>3, HCN(4-3)/CO(3-2)>0.15, HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)<3. Since HCO+ (4.2mJy) will be the weakest line we set the sensitivity such that we achieve a 5sgima detection adopting a 10km/s bandwidth splitting the line into 5 resolution elements. We will adaptively change the band width depending on the line width to achieve the same detection significance. Similarly we estimate the dust continuum based on the CO(1-0) flux within <2" that we convert into a gas mass of 6*10^9M_sun. We assume gas-to-dust ratio of 50, beam difference of 100:1 and a filling factor of 10, that leads to an expected dust mass of 10^7M_sun. For T=50K and Rayleigh-Jeans domain we expect a thermal continuum emission at 0.35mm of 0.10mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE1108-1831
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to map the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) and potentially CS(7-6) as well as the underlying thermal cold dust continuum of circumnuclear discs around luminous nearby AGN at a resolution of ~0.15-0.3".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select three spectral windows centered on the CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) in Band 7 and an additional continuum window. Since we expect a line width ranging between 20 and 400km/s per beam we can use a correlator bandwidth of 3.9MHz (3.3km/s) which is a 1/5th of the narrowest expected line width to reduce the data rate. For the additional continuum band we will use the low resolution TDM mode.

We aim to resolve the CND around the AGN which we know from the existing MUSE observation have a size of <1kpc or <2". At the redshift of the AGN, 0.2" correspond to 70pc-150pc which allows us to resolve the CND in different physical regions. We will except spatial resolutions ranging between 0.15"-0.3" to be more flexible with the antenna configuration schedule since the targets are at the limit of night time observation for the preliminary Cycle 3 schedule.

By combining the integrated IRAM 30m CO(1-0) line flux with Halpha maps at 1" resolution from MUSE integral field spectroscopy (see Fig. 2) we re-distribute the CO(1-0) flux and roughly predict the CO(1-0) flux within <2" around the nucleus, i.e. 22 Jy km/s. We take into account the ratio between that area and the beam area of 100:1 but compensate with an assumed filling factor of ~10 and adopt a median line width of 50km/s to predict the CO(1-0) peak flux density, i.e. 44 mJy. We then consider the measured intensity ratios of the CND in the prototypical AGN NGC 1068, CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)>3, HCN(4-3)/CO(3-2)>0.15, HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)<3.0. Since HCO+ (6.6mJy) will be the weakest line we set the sensitivity such that we achieve a 5sgima detection adopting a 10km/s bandwidth splitting the line into 5 resolution elements. We will adaptively change the band width depending on the line width to achieve the same detection significance. Since we cannot predict the continuum flux density from the existing data we will just perform a detection experiment at the given sensitivity. Similarly we estimate the dust continuum based on the CO(1-0) flux within <2" that we convert into a gas mass of 3*10^9M_sun. We assume gas-to-dust ratio of 50, beam difference of 100:1 and a filling factor of 10, that leads to an expected dust mass of 8*10^6M_sun. For T=50K and Rayleigh-Jeans domain we expect a thermal continuum emission at 0.35mm of 0.14mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A key question in our current picture of galaxy evolution is the interplay of AGN and their host galaxies. We have recently started the Close AGN Reference Survey (CARS) to unravel the AGN-host connection from spatially-resolved multi-wavelength data for a sample of 40 nearby luminous unobscured AGN. From optical 3D spectroscopy with MUSE at the VLT we select 4 AGN hosts with luminous circumnuclear discs (CNDs) and indications for outflows seen as broad (200-400km/s) spatially-resolved emission lines. Here, we propose ALMA observations to take a closer look on the dense gas with ALMA by mapping the relevant diagnostics lines CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) and underlying dust continuum at a resolution of ~0.2" (70-150pc). Our proposed ALMA observations will allow us to 1) characterize the size, gas/dust mass and excitation conditions of the CND in relation to AGN luminosity, BH mass and host galaxy morphology, 2) resolve the dense gas kinematics and verify the nature and geometry of the presumed AGN outflows, 3) estimate the total energy and momentum of the outflows from the cold and ionized gas phase to test whether the starburst in the CNDs or the AGN is driving the outflows.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00724.S, PI: B. Husemann, 'The Close AGN Reference Survey (CARS)- The life cycle of gas in nearby luminous AGN'
